Chapter 2. The Geometry of Linear Programming

 

2.1 Polyhedra and convex sets

The feasible set of any linear programming problem is a polyhedron.

Definition 2.1 Let A be an m×n matrix and b∈Rm.

  1. A polyhedron (in general form) is a set {x∈Rn∣Ax≥b}.

  2. A polyhedron in standard form is a set {x∈Rn∣Ax=b,x≥0}.

Theorem 2.1 (b) Every polyhedron is a convex set.

Proof. A polyhedron is the intersection of a finite number of half-spaces {x∈Rn∣aiTx≥bi}, and a half-space is convex.

 

2.2 Extreme points, vertices, and basic feasible solutions

We suggest three different ways of defining the concept of a "corner" and then show that all three definitions are equivalent.

 

Extreme point

Our first definition defines an extreme point of a polyhedron as a point that cannot be expressed as a convex combination of two other elements of the polyhedron; see Figure 2.4.

Definition 2.6 Let P be a polyhedron. A vector x∈P is an extreme point of P if we cannot find two vectors y,z∈P, both different from x, and λ∈[0,1] such that x=λy+(1−λ)z.

This definition is entirely geometric and does not refer to a specific representation of a polyhedron in terms of linear constraints.

 

Vertex

An alternative geometric definition defines a vertex of a polyhedron P as the unique optimal solution to some linear programming problem with feasible set P.

Definition 2.7 Let P be a polyhedron. A vector x∈P is a vertex of P if there exists some c∈Rn such that cTx<cTy for all y≠x∈P.

In other words, x is a vertex of P if and only if P is on one side of a hyperplane {y∈Rn∣cTy=cTx} which meets P only at x; see Figure 2.5.

 

Basic feasible solution

The third definition relies on a representation of a polyhedron in terms of linear constraints.

Consider a polyhedron P⊆Rn defined in terms of the linear equality and inequality constraints

aiTx≥bi,ajTx≤bj,akTx=bk,

where i∈M1, j∈M2, and k∈M3 are finite index sets.

Definition 2.8 If a vector x∗ satisfies aiTx∗=bi for some i∈M1, M2, or M3, we say that the corresponding constraint is active (or binding) at x∗.

We will often say that certain constraints are linearly independent if the corresponding vectors ai are linearly independent.

If there are n constraints that are active at x∗∈Rn, then x∗ becomes a solution of a certain system of n linear equations in n unknowns:

[⋮aiT⋮][⋮xj⋮]=[⋮bi⋮]

Notice that x∗ is a unique solution if and only if the n active constraints are linearly independent.

Definition 2.9 Consider a polyhedron P defined by linear equality and inequality constraints.

  • A vector x∗∈Rn is a basic solution if

    1. All equality constraints are active at x∗;

    2. There exist n linearly independent constraints that are active at x∗.

  • If x∗∈P is a basic solution, it is called a basic feasible solution.

In Figure 2.6, points A, B, and C are basic feasible solutions. Point D is not a basic solution. Point E is feasible, but not basic.

Whether a point is a basic solution or not may depend on the way that a polyhedron is represented. In Figure 2.6, D is not a basic solution, but D is a basic solution of the same polyhedron with different representation: {x∈R3∣x1+x2+x3≤1,x1+x2+x3≥1,x1≥0,x2≥0,x3≥0}.

Theorem 2.3 Let P={x∈Rn∣Ax≥b} be a nonempty polyhedron and let x∗∈P. Then the following are equivalent:

  1. x∗ is a vertex;

  2. x∗ is an extreme point;

  3. x∗​ is a basic feasible solution.

Proof. (1) ⇒ (2) If x∗ is not an extreme point, then there exist y,z∈P such that y≠x∗, z≠x∗, and x∗=λy+(1−λ)z for some 0<λ<1. Moreover, any c∈Rn satisfying cTx∗<cTy and cTx∗<cTz gives a contradiction

cTx∗=cT(λx∗+(1−λ)x∗)<cT(λy+(1−λ)z)=cTx∗.

Therefore, x∗​ is not a vertex.

Let I={i∣aiTx∗=bi} be the set of indices of constraints that are active at x∗.

(2) ⇒ (3) If x∗ is not a basic solution, then the matrix having rows ai for all i∈I has rank less than n, and so it has a nonzero kernel d∈Rn such that aiTd=0 for all i∈I. Consider y=x∗+ϵd and z=x∗−ϵd for ϵ>0. Then y≠x∗, z≠x∗, and x∗=(y+z)/2.

  • For active constraints, we have aiT(x∗±ϵd)=aiTx∗=bi for all i∈I.

  • For non-active constraints, we have aiTx∗>bi for all i∉I. Choose ϵ>0 so that ϵ|aiTd|<aiTx∗−bi for all i∉I. Then x∗±ϵd∈P, since for all i∉I,

aiT(x∗±ϵd)−bi=(aiTx∗−bi)±ϵaiTd≥(aiTx∗−bi)−ϵ|aiTd|>0.

Therefore, x∗ is not an extreme point.

(3) ⇒ (1) Let x∗ be a basic feasible solution and set c=∑i∈Iai. Notice that I≠∅.

For any y∈P, we have Ay≥b so that aiTy≥bi for all i. It follows that x∗=miny∈PcTy, since

cTy=∑i∈IaiTy≥∑i∈Ibi=∑i∈IaiTx∗=cTx∗.

We claim that cTy=cTx∗ implies y=x∗ for any y∈P. Then x∗ is a vertex of P.

Suppose cTy=∑i∈IaiTy=∑i∈Ibi=cTx∗. Since aiTy≥bi, we must have aiTy=bi for all i∈I. By assumption, x∗ is a basic solution so that x∗ is a unique solution to the system of equations aiTx=bi for all active constraints, i∈I. Therefore y=x∗.

Note that the property of being a basic feasible solution (algebraic) is independent of the representation of a polyhedron, since the definitions of "vertex" and "extreme point" are geometric.

Corollary 2.1 Given a finite number of linear inequality constraints, there can only be a finite number of basic or basic feasible solutions.

Proof. Different basic solutions correspond to different sets of n linearly independent active constraints.

 

Adjacent basic solution

Two distinct basic solutions in Rn are said to be adjacent if we can find n−1 linearly independent constraints that are active at both of them. In Figure 2.7, D and E are adjacent to B; also, A and C are adjacent to D​​.

If two adjacent basic solutions are also feasible, then the line segment that joins them is called an edge of the feasible set.

 

2.3 Polyhedra in standard form

Let P={x∈Rn∣Ax=b,x≥0} be a polyhedron in standard form, where A is an m×n matrix with linearly independent rows. (It requires that m=rankA≤n.)

  • In standard form, there are m+n candidates for active constraint; m constraints aiTx=bi for 1≤i≤m from Ax=b and the other n constraints 1jTx=xj=0 for 1≤j≤n from x≥0, where 1j∈Rn is the unit vector such that all entries are zero except for one at the index j.

  • If x is a basic solution, we have (1) m (linearly independent) active constraints from Ax=b, and (2) n linearly independent active constraints which may not contain all of the m active constraints aiTx=bi.

  • However, it is always possible to find another n linearly independent active constraints containing all of the m active constraints aiTx=bi, since the rows {ai∣1≤i≤m} of A​ are linearly independent.

  • In this case, we have an n×n non-singular active constraint matrix A~ with m rows aiT for 1≤i≤m, and n−m rows of the form 1jT for j∈J⊆{1,…,n} such that |J|=n−m​.

Theorem 2.4 Let P={x∈Rn∣Ax=b,x≥0} be a polyhedron in standard form, where A is an m×n matrix with linearly independent rows. A vector x∈Rn is a basic solution of P if and only if Ax=b, and there exist indices B1,…,Bm such that

  1. The columns AB1,…,ABm are linearly independent;

  2. If j∈J={B1,…,Bm}C, then xj=0.

Proof. (⇐) We have m active constraints aiTx=bi for 1≤i≤m from Ax=b and the other n−m active constraints {xj=0∣j∈J}. It remains to show that these n constraints are linearly independent. Suppose that aiTy=0 for 1≤i≤m and yj=0 for all j∈J. Since the columns AB1,…,ABm are linearly independent, we have

0=Ay=∑k=1mABkyBk⟹yBk=0 for 1≤k≤m⟹y=0.

(⇒) We may assume that there are n linearly independent active constraints; m constraints aiTx=bi for 1≤i≤m from Ax=b, and n−m constraints xj=0 for j∈J⊆{1,…,n}. Since |J|=n−m, we can choose the other m indices, B1,…,Bm∉J.

(2) follows immediately, and (1) follows from the fact that A~​ is non-singular.

Procedure for constructing basic solutions

  1. Choose m linearly independent columns AB1,…,ABm.

  2. Let xj=0 for all j∉{B1,…,Bm}.

  3. Solve the system of m equations Ax=b for the unknowns xB1,…,xBm.

If a basic solution constructed according to this procedure is nonnegative, then it is feasible, and it is a basic feasible solution.

If x is a basic solution, the variables xB1,…,xBm are called basic variables; the remaining variables are called nonbasic. The columns AB1,…,ABm are called the basic columns, and they form a basis of Rm.

By arranging the m basic columns next to each other, we obtain an m×m matrix B, called a basis matrix. We can similarly define a vector xB with the values of the basic variables.

B=[|||AB1AB2⋯ABm|||],xB=[xB1⋮xBm].

The basic variables are determined by solving the equation BxB=b whose unique solution is given by xB=B−1b​.

 

Correspondence of bases and basic solutions

Different basic solutions must correspond to different bases, because a basis uniquely determines a basic solution, i.e., {bases} → {basic solutions} is a map. However, two different bases may lead to the same basic solution, i.e., the map is not one-to-one.

 

The full row rank assumption on A

Theorem 2.5 Let P={x∈Rn∣Ax=b,x≥0} be a nonempty polyhedron, where A is an m×n matrix. Suppose that rankA=k<m and that the rows ai1T,…,aikT are linearly independent. Then

P=Q={x∈Rn∣ai1Tx=bi1,…,aikTx=bikx≥0}.

Proof. (⊆) is trivial. (⊇) Since any row aiT of A can be expressed in a linear combination of ai1T,…,aikT and x∈P≠∅, we have

bi=aiTx=∑j=1kλiijaijTx=∑j=1kλiijbij.

Thus y∈Q, i.e., aijTy=bij for all 1≤j≤k implies aiTy=bi for all 1≤i≤m, i.e., y∈P.

As long as the feasible set is nonempty, a linear programming problem in standard form can be reduced to an equivalent standard form problem (with the same feasible set) in which the equality constraints are linearly independent.

 

2.4 Degeneracy

Definition 2.10 A basic solution x∈Rn is said to be degenerate if more than n of the constraints are active at x.

 

Degeneracy in standard form polyhedra

Definition 2.11 Let P={x∈Rn∣Ax=b,x≥0} be a polyhedron in standard form where A is an m×n matrix. A basic solution x is called degenerate if more than n−m of the components of x are zero.

 

Degeneracy is not a purely geometric property

A degenerate basic feasible solution under one representation could be nondegenerate under another representation.

The vector (0,0,1) is a degenerate basic feasible solution in the standard form polyhedron

P={(x1,x2,x3)∣x1−x2=0,x1+x2+2x3=2,x1,x2,x3≥0},

but it is not degenerate in the (non-standard form) polyhedron

P={(x1,x2,x3)∣x1−x2=0,x1+x2+2x3=2,x1≥0,x3≥0}.

However, if a basic feasible solution is degenerate under one particular standard form representation, then it is degenerate under every standard form representation of the same polyhedron.

 

2.5 Existence of extreme points

Definition 2.12 A polyhedron P={x∈Rn∣Ax≥b} contains a line if there exist x∈P and d≠0∈Rn such that x+λd∈P for all λ∈R​.

If P contains a line x+λd, then aiT(x+λd)≥bi for all 1≤i≤m and for all λ∈R. It follows that aiTd=0, i.e., d∈kerA≠{0}.

(∵) If aiTd>0 (or aiTd<0), we can pick λ→−∞ (or ∞​) to violate the constraint.

On the other hand, if nonzero d∈kerA≠{0}, then P contains a line x+λd, since aiT(x+λd)=aiTx≥bi for all 1≤i≤m and for all λ∈R.

Theorem 2.6 Let P={x∈Rn∣Ax≥b} be a nonempty polyhedron, where A is an m×n matrix. Then the following are equivalent:

  1. P has at least one extreme point, or one basic feasible solution.

  2. P does not contain a line, or ker⁡A={0}.

Proof. (1) ⇒ (2) If P has a basic feasible solution x, then there exist n linearly independent constraints that are active at x; in other words rankA=n or kerA={0}.

(2) ⇒ (1) Choose x∈P≠∅ and let I={i∣aiTx=bi} be the set of indices of active constraints. If the rank of {ai∣i∈I}=n, then x is a basic feasible solution and done. Otherwise, there exists d≠0∈Rn such that aiTd=0 for all i∈I.

For i∈I, we have aiTx=bi and aiTd=0 so that aiT(x+λd)=bi for all λ∈R​. Notice that x+λd∈P for sufficiently small |λ|, since

{y∈Rn∣akTy>bk for all k∉I and aiTy=bi for all i∈I}

is open in P∩{y∈Rn∣aiTy=bi for all i∈I}.

By assumption, P does not contain a line so that as we vary λ, some constraint will be eventually violated. In other words, there exists λ∗∈R and k∉I such that akT(x+λ∗d)=bk. Moreover, ak is not a linear combination of {ai∣i∈I}. (∵) Since aiTd=0 for all i∈I, any linear combination of {ai∣i∈I} is orthogonal to d. But akTx>bk.

Thus, by moving from x to x+λ∗d, the number of linear independent active constraints has been increased by at least one. By repeating the same argument, as many times as needed, we eventually end up with a point at which there are n linearly independent active constraints. (See Figure 2.14.)

Corollary 2.2 Every nonempty bounded polyhedron and every nonempty polyhedron in standard form has at least one basic feasible solution.

 

2.6 Optimality of extreme points

Theorem 2.7 Let P={x∈Rn∣Ax≥b} be a polyhedron having at least one extreme point. If a linear programming problem over P has an optimal solution, then it also has an extreme point which is optimal.

Proof. Let Q={x∈Rn∣Ax≥b,cTx=v}≠∅ be the set of all optimal solutions, where v is the optimal value. Then Q⊆P is also a polyhedron having at least one extreme point. (∵) P has an extreme point ⇒ P does not have a line ⇒ Q does not have a line ⇒ Q has an extreme point.

We claim that an extreme point x∗ of Q is also an extreme point of P. If not, there exist y,z∈P such that y≠x, z≠x, and x∗=λy+(1−λ)z for some λ∈[0,1]. Since cTy≥v and cTz≥v,

v=cTx∗=λcTy+(1−λ)cTz≥λv+(1−λ)v=v⟹cTy=cTz=v⟹y,z∈Q

which contradicts to that x∗ is an extreme point of Q​.

Theorem 2.7 applies to a polyhedron in standard form, as well as to a bounded polyhedron, since it has at least one extreme point by Corollary 2.2.

Theorem 2.8 Let P={x∈Rn∣Ax≥b} be a polyhedron having at least one extreme point. A linear programming problem over P has either the optimal cost −∞​ or an extreme point which is optimal.

Theorem 2.7의 증명에서 extreme point를 찾을 때 objective function cTx를 줄이는 방향으로 d를 선택할 수 있다. 즉, cTd≤0. 이 경우, 반직선 x+λd for λ≥0에 대해 cT(x+λd)≤cTx​​이 성립한다.

  • If cTd=0, then cT(x+λd)=cTx for all λ∈R. 가정에 의해 직선이 모두 P에 들어갈 수는 없다.

  • If cTd<0, then cT(x+λd)→−∞ as λ→∞. 이 경우, 반직선이 모두 P에 들어가면 optimal cost는 −∞가 된다.

그렇지 않다면 akT(x+λ∗d)=bk가 되는 λ∗≥0와 k∉I가 존재하게 된다. 즉, cT(x+λ∗d)≤cTx.

For a general linear programming problem, if the feasible set P has no extreme point, then Theorem 2.8 does not apply directly. On the other hand, any linear programming problem can be transformed into an equivalent problem in standard form to which Theorem 2.8 does apply.

Corollary 2.3 A linear programming problem over a nonempty polyhedron has either the optimal cost −∞​ or an optimal solution.

In the nonlinear problem of minimizing 1/x subject to x≥1, the optimal cost is not −∞, but an optimal solution does not exist.

 

2.9 Summary

Let P={x∈Rn∣Ax≥b} be a nonempty feasible set (polyhedron).

  • If​ P is bounded, there exists an optimal solution. (∵ P is compact so that the image of the object function is also compact.) Furthermore, there exists an optimal solution which is an extreme point. (Corollary 2.2 and Theorem 2.8)

  • If P is unbounded, there are the following possibilities:

    1. There exists an optimal solution which is an extreme point.

      • This can only happen when P has at least one extreme point. For example, P={(x1,x2)∈R2∣x1≥0,x2≥0} and c=(1,1)​​.

    2. There exists an optimal solution, but no optimal solution is an extreme point.

      • This can only happen when P has no extreme points; it never happens when the problem is in standard form. For example, P={(x1,x2)∈R2∣x2≥0} and c=(0,1). It is equivalent to the standard form P={(x1+,x1−,x2)∈R3∣x1+,x1−,x2≥0} and c=(0,0,1).

    3. The optimal cost is −∞. For example,

      • (with extreme point) P={(x1,x2)∈R2∣x1≥0,x2≥0} and c=(−1,−1).

      • (no extreme point) P={(x1,x2)∈R2∣x2≥0} and c=(0,−1).

The distinction between geometric properties of a polyhedron and those properties that depend on a particular representation.

  • Whether or not a point is an extreme point (or basic feasible solution) is a geometric property.

  • Whether or not a point is a basic solution may depend on the way that a polyhedron is represented.

  • Whether or not a basic or basic feasible solution is degenerate may depend on the way that a polyhedron is represented.
